text: hm is a very famous patient who suffered
memory loss and had an absolutely
transformative effect that our
understanding of memory in the brain he
had a very severe case of epilepsy that
could not be treated pharmacologically
with with medical treatments drug
treatments and so they performed surgery
on him when he was in his late 20s and
removed the focus of where the epileptic
seizures were taking place and that
location often in epilepsy is in an area
called the hippocampus which is kind of
on the side of the brain inside the
center of the medial temporal lobe
the good news was that that surgical
treatment helped cure the Epilepsy the
unexpected bad news was that HM was no
longer able to form new memories so he
didn't really lose memories of from the
lifetime but the doctor would come in
every day and every day HM didn't
recognize the doctor and if you try to
probe HM to remember what he did
yesterday and tell you about it he
couldn't he couldn't create new memories
after losing this part of the brain and
this was scientifically astonishing
because most of the theories and
neuroscience up until that point about
localization of memory in the brain from
previous century had indicated from
animal research that memories are not in
one part of the brain they're
distributed all over and what happened
to HM reveal the no actually there's one
part of the brain that seems to be
important crucially important for one
kind of memory which is kind of that
creating a record of what we will
typically think of memory what you had
for breakfast yesterday very interesting
thing has happened with HM and it's
actually exciting to have the
opportunity to talk about HM today
because one of the most famous
scientists who interrogated HMS memory
over a lifetime was through korkin from
MIT and she passed away about a week ago
and hm passed away several years ago and
so anybody who's interested about it and
and did amazing work and kept on
interrogating him and doing research on
his memory and that's turned out to be
really interesting because the first
past results led to the consensus that
this part of the brain was specialized
for what people called the clear ative
memory the ability to remember what
happened yesterday or the day before and
that everything else was intact
like imagination and creativity and
morality and so forth
over the years that turned out to not be
true and that there were a lot of other
more subtle changes in HMS behavior and
since then we have many more people that
have damaged the data campus because of
hypoxia or encephalitis various other
situations and these people suffer many
of them from memory loss but
understanding that what that memory is
turns out to be much more complicated in
one example that I think is related
potentially to morality although I again
you know I don't know tell me what you
think is that if you just ask people to
imagine a scenario a hypothetical
scenario which it sounds like often
happens in sort of assessments of moral
judgments that without a hippocampus
people don't imagine that scenario in
the same way they imagine it in a very
impoverished way so if I just asked you
imagine this event is unfolding in two
years
tell me about it and it's here if your
birthday in two years most of us go into
a lot of detail and apparently vividly
imagine it people with damage to the
hippocampus which our textbooks tell us
of just memory don't imagine that in
detail at all they give a very very
vague kind of sense of what's going to
happen
